Topic.Title: Question: Will Yahoo Buy Zynga ?

Message.Msg: It is interesting that everyone talks abouj what Yahoo should BUY. That is a tacit admission that their existing activities/business either aren't worth very much, aren't doing very well, can't be fixed or are so badly managed that they will soon be worthlesss. If Yahoo can't run what it owns now, what makes anyone think they willl do any better with an acqusition? Yahoo has some really serious managment and corporate culture problems. Anything they acquire will be contaminated by Yahoo; Yahoo won't be improved by the acquisiotns.

Message.Title: Terry Semel is back!!??!!
Message.Msg: "Chief Executive" redirects here. For other uses, see Chief executive (disambiguation). "CEO" and "CEOs" redirect here. For the island, see Ceos. For the musical project, see ceo (musician). For the Angolan airport with this IATA code, see Waco Kungo Airport. A chief executive officer (CEO, American English), managing director (MD, British English),[1] executive director (ED, American English) for non-profit organizations, or chief executive (CE, British English) [2] is the highest-ranking corporate officer (executive) or administrator in charge of total management of an organization. An individual appointed as a CEO of a corporation, company, organization, or agency typically reports to the board of directors.

Topic.Title: Bought Yahoo @ $15.02

Message.Msg: All I can say is $15.02 is $1.00 below $16.02 I think the 'news' of giving the CEO the power to 'buy' things w/the $4.2 bln is a classic corp/mgnt mistake. What usually happens to the stock price of the acquiring comp on the announcement? Good purchase/bad purchase, etc., YHOO will end up 'paying up' for everything they 'buy' and it will take at least 2 yrs to 'return' anything. Hate to say it, this is a L-T strategic move to allow the CEO to 'spend'.....which is classic. The CEO is off the hook because she'll say "It will eventually pay off for YHOO shr-hlders." Key word is "eventually." I think this stock is headed towards a $14 handle....in a 'down mkt', faster than in a sideways one....regardless....it's going lower. Bad decision; period!!!

Topic.Title: Marissa is doing what's best for the company.

Message.Msg: What about buying Alibaba? That seems to me to be an intelligent deployment of capital. While this bleeding is certainly concerning to me, I am also confused a bit by the reaction. MM is hired and the investment community applauds the decision. They say she is whip-smart, determined, and as able as anyone to effectively lead. It must be assumed that part of the fanfare was for the possibility of a YHOO turnaround, no? Why would we need a hotshot just to unwind and distribute YHOO's assets? And if she were to to this, what would become of YHOO afterwards? We are losing the investors that bought for the quick money, plain and simple. The capitulation will cease, YHOO will stabilize, and MM will either succeed or fail. I believe she will succeed. I believe YHOO has so much potential. I believe that YHOO could be in the HUNDREDS if successfully turned around.

Message.Title: Hey Marissa, You Listening To The Market?
Message.Msg: It's telling you it doesn't like uncertainty. Why in the world would you announce a possible "take-away" without announcing that if you do, in fact, take something away what investors will get in return? It's like talking about problems without offering solutions. Speaking for myself, I still have faith but am admittedly disappointed with the manner in which the Alibaba matter has been handled thus far. Please let your intentions be known soon, shareholders have been through quite a bit in the recent past with this company and you and the board owe us more transparency as a result.

Topic.Title: Marissa is doing what's best for the company.

Message.Msg: I agree. Why should shareholders be so trusting of MM that she will magically do the right thing after her nebulous "review"? This is business, not religion. Blind faith has no place in this arena. We will believe in her when she proves something to us. Anything. This is particularly so when "Yahoo" has been more like "yo-yo" in the past year, first looking to sell a minority interest in itself, then looking to sell back parts of its Asian holdings; going through 3 (so far) "permanent" CEO's and two or three interim CEO's in the past year; announcing that it was going to be a "media" company and then just a quickly announcing that it was going to be a "tech" company instead; telling shareholders (when board elections were about to take place) that the Alibaba money was going to be used for dividends/share buybacks and then suddenly indicating that it may be used to buy undisclosed businesses; telling everyone that Yahoo was going to get smaller, leaner and more focused by cutting certain parts of its operation and terminating thousands of employees and then suggesting recently that Yahoo will be expanding by buying out other companies and hiring potentially thousands of new engineers. . . And all the while the stock has been painfully flat for ages and ages -- with no definitive plan and an apparent reneging on the plan which had been announced. People who are YHOO shareholders can be accused of being a lot of things, but not being "ingrates" and not irrationally demanding "instant gratification." We've been patient, patient and more patient. So far, our patience has been anything but rewarded. And, although MM has admittedly been in command only a short time, the only thing MM has managed to do is to preside over the departure of the valuable Ross Levinsohn and deflate the price of YAHOO stock at a time when it finally seemed like it was going to move in a positive direction. Ingrates? I hardly think so. Yahoo shareholders are just like any other investors. We're looking for dividends or growth or both -- and we're looking for some sign that management knows what the hell it is doing. So far, the company is 0-for-3 in those categories. I continue to think this stock is undervalued and buy more on the dips. I bought 1,000 more shares today at $14.86, on the belief that the market will eventually value this thing at $18 or more. But we do need some help from the BOD and our new CEO. It's more than time to start producing some positive results.

Message.Title: BuyBack
Message.Msg: while I generally don't support buybacks, I do think there is a time and place for them. At below $15 per share they ought to be buying every share possible. Special dividends do very little to support LT value but buybacks can if done at the right time. Use the pile of cash and start buying back at these levels. If the BOD thinks they are undervalued by turning down $30 per share offers than the best investment they can make is in their own stock at half that. If they don't buyback then what does that tell about the confidence in their company and brand. Release a statement today!

Message.Title: The dread splash-0-meter
Message.Msg: If one has been watching the recent Olympics diving on NBC in the evening, the last thing any diver would like do upon entry is agitate the splash meter too much. (But even the superb Chinese diver couldnâ€™t do a towering entry without incurring some splash.) And now Marissa has made her grand entry with the inevitable splash, perhaps a bit too much too soon. I have been a longtime Yahoo long until about a fortnight ago; I posted then 5 reasons for the change of heart. I might now add another for unloading recently: To avoid a fat-tail event like the present one unfolding. To be sure, nothing significant has been implemented yet since her arrival at Yahoo but for the cumulative angst over what she will actually do next is what that is driving the stock down. Her penchant for a seeming dose of shock therapy is unnerving investors. Instead of planning to inject sudden and large doses of nostrums which will be hard on digestion, she should space out her revamping program. It is not right to put YHOO investors through the current wringer in mere anticipation of her next not so secret gambit that screams for total clarification...a more experienced CEO would have carefully avoided giving the impression of embarking on a regimen of shock therapy. ...to be continued...

Topic.Title: The dread splash-0-meter

Message.Msg: ...continue... It was a bold move for powerbroker Dan to pick Marissa. She now has an uphill challenge ahead to say the least balancing the short-term shareholder interest against the long-term future of a Yahoo (to be remade in the image of Google?). Meg Whitman could not slingshot HPQ forward in less than a year, so expect no overnight miracle from Marissa either. Diehard stakeholders in Yahoo would have to be very patient with her at a minimum of 4 to 8 quarters and hope for the best.

Message.Title: Marissa must have put forward a good idea during her interview
Message.Msg: The question is - what was or is that idea? It looked like yhoo was all set to hand the job to their interim CEO., folks seemed to trust him, and the pps was at least stable as folks waited for the cash to roll in...but Marissa ended up getting the job. ??????? What new possibilities did she see? What great idea(s) did she present? How did she see the future of the company differently? No doubt her idea is linked to the shift in use of the first distribution from Alibaba. What was so exciting, so different, and what about it had such great potential that yahoo! shifted course to accommodate the new plan? Unfortunately all shareholders have seen since last Thursday is a big NO, as in no cash, no plan, no gains, and huge losses. Did she - bring them a buyer? (why give away the cash if you are going to sell - the cash is attractive). Did she - Link them up with a solid "done deal", something that others could not do? ..this may take some time to manifest itself (while all except the shorts panic) She might have even explained to a greedy board that the cash proceeds from Alibaba part 1 and Alibaba part 2, along with the proceeds from Yahoo Japan and existing cash could be used to take yahoo private----as in not just buy back some but most of the shares as the prices fall....then make a "generous offer" of say 16 or 17 for the rest [I am just playing here, because this would result in mega law suits and litigation that would last forever]
